channel.title: Morning Agriculture
channel.description: Delivered every Monday by 10 a.m., Weekly Agriculture examines the latest news in agriculture and food politics and policy.

item.title: Parties jockey for farmers’ favor
item.description: With the midterms looming, Democrats and Republicans are already jockeying for the support of farmers and rural voters.
item.dc:creator: By Rachel Shin

item.title: How the new shutdown deal impacts ag
item.description: Senators voted to break the shutdown stalemate, paving the way for the government to reopen and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program to return to normal funding levels.
item.dc:creator: By Rachel Shin

item.title: The day SNAP stopped
item.description: Food bank directors said the weekend was marked by a rising sense of panic and a flood of new customers who relied on SNAP benefits.
item.dc:creator: By Rachel Shin

item.title: Food aid funding fury
item.description: USDA announced over the weekend that there will be no SNAP benefits starting Nov. 1 due to the ongoing federal shutdown.
item.dc:creator: By Grace Yarrow

item.title: 6 shutdown pain points
item.description: With just two weeks until the end of October, this week's shutdown negotiations could be a crossroads for food and farm programs' funding plans.
item.dc:creator: By Grace Yarrow

item.title: Dems' soybean blitz
item.description: Democrats are launching an agriculture-centered opening argument ahead of the midterm campaign season, slamming Trump’s tariffs for hurting soybean producers and other farmers that have traditionally backed the president.
item.dc:creator: By Grace Yarrow

item.title: Farmers left in limbo with aid on the line
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent teased an announcement of "substantial support for the farmers" coming this week.
item.dc:creator: By Grace Yarrow

item.title: Trump’s soybean sacrifice
item.description: Six months after the president’s “Liberation Day” tariffs and weeks from the Nov. 10 White House cutoff for a trade pact between the two countries, U.S. soybean farmers are learning that China — long the predominant market for their product — doesn’t need them anymore.
item.dc:creator: By Grace Yarrow

item.title: USDA ends food insecurity survey
item.description: The Trump administration confirmed reports Saturday that it is canceling the yearly Household Food Security Reports, calling the publication of the data “redundant, costly, politicized, and extraneous.”
item.dc:creator: By Grace Yarrow
